{{short description|17th-century English noble}} {{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox nobility | name = Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton | image = Wriothesley southampton.jpg | caption = Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton, in the [[Tower of London]] in 1603, attributed to [[John de Critz]]. A small painting of the Tower of London is shown in the top-right background, above the Latin words: ''In vinculis invictus'' ("in chains unconquered") ''February 8, 1600; 601; 602; 603 April''. The arms of Wriothesley (''Azure, a cross or between four hawks close argent'') are | spouse = [[Elizabeth Wriothesley, Countess of Southampton|Elizabeth Vernon]] | issue = Penelope Wriothesley
[[James Wriothesley, Lord Wriothesley]]
[[Thomas Wriothesley, 4th Earl of Southampton|Thomas Wriothesley]]
Anne Wriothesley | father = [[Henry Wriothesley, 2nd Earl of Southampton]] | mother = [[Mary Wriothesley, Countess of Southampton|Mary Browne]] | birth_date = 6 October 1573 | birth_place = [[Cowdray House]], [[Sussex]], England | death_date = {{death date and age|1624|11|10|1573|10|6|df=y}} | death_place = [[Bergen op Zoom]], [[Dutch Republic]] }} [[File:WriothesleyArms.png|thumb|200px|Arms of Wriothesley: ''Azure, a cross or between four hawks close argent'']] [[File:Coat of arms of Sir Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton, KG.png|thumb|[[Quartering (heraldry)|Quartered]] arms of Sir Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton, KG: Quarterly of four: ''Azure, a cross or between four hawks close argent'' (Wriothesley); 2nd: ''Argent, a fret gules on a canton of the second a lion passant or'' (unknown); 3rd: ''Argent, five fusils conjoined in pale gules a bordure azure bezantée'' (unknown); 4th: ''Per pale indented gules and azure, a lion rampant or''[http://www.geog.port.ac.uk/webmap/hantsmap/hantsmap/topics/blazon09.htm Blazon of arms here depicted, contrast with other images see]]] [[File:Mary (Browne) Wriothesley Countess of Southampton.jpg|thumb|Southampton's mother, [[Mary Wriothesley, Countess of Southampton]] (1552–1607)]] [[File:Cobbe Portrait of Southampton.jpg|thumb|Southampton in his teens, ''c.'' 1590–93, attributed to [[John de Critz]]]] '''Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|sep=,|KG|}} (6 October 1573 – 10 November 1624), (pronunciation uncertain: {{IPAc-en|'|r|ɛ|z|l|i}} "Rezley",{{Harvnb|Stopes|1922|p=12}} {{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|aɪ|z|l|i}} "Rizely" (archaic),{{Harvnb|Montague-Smith|1977|p=410}} {{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|ɒ|t|s|l|i}} (present-day) and {{IPAc-en|ˈ|r|aɪ|ə|θ|s|l|i}}{{Harvnb|Wells|2008}} have been suggested), was the only son of [[Henry Wriothesley, 2nd Earl of Southampton]], and [[Mary Wriothesley, Countess of Southampton|Mary Browne]], daughter of [[Anthony Browne, 1st Viscount Montagu]]. [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] two narrative poems, ''[[Venus and Adonis (Shakespeare poem)|Venus and Adonis]]'' and ''[[The Rape of Lucrece]]'', were dedicated to Southampton, who is frequently identified as the [[Fair Youth]] of [[Shakespeare's Sonnets]]. ==Family== Henry Wriothesley, born 6 October 1573 at [[Cowdray House]], Sussex, was the only son of [[Henry Wriothesley, 2nd Earl of Southampton]], by [[Mary Wriothesley, Countess of Southampton|Mary Browne]], the only daughter of [[Anthony Browne, 1st Viscount Montagu]]e, and his first wife, [[Jane Browne, Viscountess Montague|Jane Radcliffe]].{{Harvnb|Richardson III|2011|p=228}}. He had two sisters, Jane, who died before 1573, and Mary (c.1567 – 1607), who in June 1585 married [[Thomas Arundell, 1st Baron Arundell of Wardour]].{{Harvnb|Cokayne|1953|p=128}}; {{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=12, 27}}; {{Harvnb|Elzinga|2004}};. After his father's death, Southampton's mother married firstly, on 2 May 1595, as his second wife, [[Thomas Heneage|Sir Thomas Heneage]] (d. 17 October 1595), [[Vice-Chamberlain of the Household]], and secondly, between 5 November 1598 and 31 January 1599, [[William Hervey, 1st Baron Hervey|Sir William Hervey]]. She died in November 1607.{{Harvnb|Cokayne|1953|p=127}}; {{Harvnb|Elzinga|2004}}; {{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|p=74}}. ==Early life== When his father died on 4 October 1581 Southampton inherited the earldom and landed income valued at £1097 6s per annum. His wardship and marriage were sold by the [[Elizabeth I of England|Queen]] to her kinsman, [[Charles Howard, 1st Earl of Nottingham|Charles, Lord Howard of Effingham]], for £1000. According to Akrigg, Howard then "entered into some further agreement, of which no documentation can now be found, which transferred to [[William Cecil, 1st Baron Burghley|Lord Burghley]] personally the custody and marriage of the young Earl, but left Howard holding his lands", and late in 1581 or early in 1582 Southampton, then eight years of age, came to live at [[Cecil House]] in the [[Strand, London|Strand]].{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=21–3}}. In October 1585, at age twelve, Southampton entered [[St John's College, Cambridge]],Cokayne states that he matriculated 11 December 1585. graduating M.A. on 6 June 1589.{{acad|id=WRTY585H|name=Wriothesley, Henry, 4th Earl of Southampton}}; {{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=28, 30}}; {{Harvnb|Cokayne|1953|p=128}}. His name was entered at the [[Gray's Inn]] legal society before he left the university, and he was admitted on 29 February 1588.{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|p=30}}; {{Harvnb|Cokayne|1953|p=128}}. On Southampton's 16th birthday, 6 October 1589, Lord Burghley noted Southampton's age in his diary, and by 1590 Burghley was negotiating with Southampton's grandfather, [[Anthony Browne, 1st Viscount Montagu]]e, and Southampton's mother, [[Mary Wriothesley, Countess of Southampton|Mary]], for a marriage between Southampton and Lord Burghley's eldest granddaughter, [[Elizabeth de Vere, Countess of Derby|Elizabeth Vere]], daughter of Burghley's daughter, [[Anne Cecil]], and [[Edward de Vere, 17th Earl of Oxford]].{{sfn|Honan|2012}} However the match was not to Southampton's liking, and in a letter written in November 1594, about six weeks after Southampton had turned 21, the Jesuit [[Henry Garnet]] reported the rumour that "The young Erle of Southampton refusing the Lady Veere payeth £5000 of present payment".{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=31–2, 39}}; {{Harvnb|Stopes|1922|pp=35–8, 86}}. In 1591 Lord Burghley's Clerk in Chancery, [[John Clapham (historian and poet)|John Clapham]], dedicated to Southampton a poem in Latin, ''Narcissus'', recounting the Greek legend of a beautiful young man who perishes through self-love. According to Akrigg, Southampton was now spending much of his time at court. He was in attendance when Queen Elizabeth visited [[University of Oxford|Oxford]] in late September 1592, and was praised fulsomely in the Latin poem written by John Sandford to commemorate the Queen's visit. In October 1592 Southampton's grandfather, [[Anthony Browne, 1st Viscount Montagu|Viscount Montague]], died. Montague had been a [[Order of the Garter|Knight of the Garter]], and on 3 May 1593 Philip Gawdy of [[Clifford's Inn]] (a law school and [[Inn of Chancery]]) wrote to his brother, [[Bassingbourne Gawdy (died 1606)|Bassingbourne Gawdy]], that Southampton had been nominated to the Order, together with the [[John Puckering|Lord Keeper]], [[Thomas Burgh, 3rd Baron Burgh|Lord Burgh]], and [[Peregrine Bertie, 13th Baron Willoughby de Eresby|Lord Willoughby de Eresby]]. Shortly thereafter, in his ''Honour of the Garter'' dated 26 June 1593, [[George Peele]] referred to him as "Gentle Wriothesley, Southampton's star", claiming erroneously that an Earl of Southampton had been among the founding Knights.{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=33–6}}; {{Harvnb|Honan|2012}}; {{Harvnb|Romilly|1879|pp=521–2}}; {{Harvnb|Dyce|1829|p=233}}. However it was not until 1603 that Southampton was invested in the Order under [[James VI and I|King James]]. ==Southampton and Shakespeare== [[File:Miniature of Henry Wriothesley, 3rd Earl of Southampton, 1594. (Fitzwilliam Museum) cropped.png|thumb|160px|left|Henry Wriothesley at 21]] [[File:Dedication page of The Rape of Lucrece by William Shakespeare 1594.jpg|thumb|right|210px|[[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare's]] [[Dedication (publishing)|dedication]] to Southampton of ''[[The Rape of Lucrece]]'', 1594]] In 1593 [[William Shakespeare|Shakespeare]] dedicated his narrative poem ''[[Venus and Adonis (Shakespeare poem)|Venus and Adonis]]'' to Southampton, followed in 1594 by ''The Rape of Lucrece''. Although the dedication to ''Venus and Adonis'' is more restrained, the dedication to ''The Rape of Lucrece'' is couched in extravagant terms: "The love I dedicate to your lordship is without end ... What I have done is yours; what I have to do is yours; being part in all I have, devoted yours." This type of vaunting language was not particularly unusual though, because other dedications of the day always excessively praised any noble person sponsoring the author's work – mainly for political, and above all financial, reasons. [[Nathan Drake (essayist and physician)|Nathan Drake]], in ''Shakespeare and his Times'', was the first to suggest that Southampton was not only the dedicatee of Shakespeare's two long narrative poems, but also the "Fair Youth" of the ''Sonnets''.{{Harvnb|Drake|1817|p=62}}. The title page refers to the "onlie begetter of these {{Not a typo|in|suing}} [[Shakespeare's Sonnets|sonnets]] Mr W.H.," and it had earlier been inferred that the ''Sonnets'' were addressed to "Mr. W.H.". Drake, however, adopting [[George Chalmers (antiquarian)|Chalmers']] suggestion that one meaning of "beget" is "bring forth", argued that Mr. W.H. was merely the procurer of the manuscript rather than the "Fair Youth" addressed in the poems.{{Harvnb|Drake|1817|pp=58–9}}. Other adherents of the theory that Southampton was the addressee of the ''Sonnets'' have suggested that his initials, H.W. (Henry Wriothesley), were simply reversed by the publisher to conceal his identity.{{sfn|Honan|1998|p=361}} However Honan argues that although Southampton "may be involved in Shakespeare's sonnets", "there is no real likelihood that he traduced him by drawing his portrait as the fickle, treacherous Young Man of the sonnets, who is implicitly 'lascivious' (sonnet 95), 'sensual' to a 'fault' or to his 'shame' (sonnets 34, 35), and ridden with vices".{{sfn|Honan|2012}} Despite extensive archival research, no documents have been found concerning their relationship apart from the dedications to Shakespeare's two long narrative poems. [[Nicholas Rowe (dramatist)|Nicholas Rowe]], on the authority of poet and playwright [[William Davenant]] (1606 – 7 April 1668), stated in his ''Life of Shakespeare'' that Southampton once gave Shakespeare £1000 to "go through with a purchase,"{{cite book|last1=Rowe|first1=Nicholas|title=Some Account of the Life, &c. of Mr. William Shakespear|date=1709|publisher=Jacob Tonson|location=London|page=x [i.e., Roman numeral 10]}} but Honan terms this a myth.{{sfn|Honan|2012}} ==The 1590s== Southampton received dedications from other writers in the 1590s. On 27 June 1593 [[Thomas Nashe]] completed his [[picaresque novel]], ''[[The Unfortunate Traveller]]'', and dedicated it to Southampton,The dedication was withdrawn from the second edition. terming him "a dere lover and cherisher . . . as well of the lovers of Poets, as of Poets themselves",{{Harvnb|McKerrow|1958|pp=252, 255}}; {{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=37–8}}. and in 1593 [[Barnabe Barnes]] published ''Parthenophil and Parthenope'' with a dedicatory sonnet to Southampton.{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|p=38}}. In 1595 [[Gervase Markham]] included a dedicatory sonnet to Southampton in ''The Most Honorable Tragedy of Richard Grinvile, Knight''.{{Harvnb|Steggle|2004}}. On 2 March 1596 [[Giovanni Florio|John Florio's]] Italian/English dictionary was entered in the Stationers' Register.It was not published until 1598. In his dedication, Florio, who was for some years in the Earl's "pay and patronage", complimented Southampton on his fluency in Italian, saying he "had become so complete a master of Italian as to have no need of travel abroad to perfect his mastery of that tongue".{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|p=53}}. In 1597 [[Henry Lok]] included a sonnet to Southampton among the sixty dedicatory sonnets in his ''Sundry Christian Passions''.{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=53–4}}. In the same year [[William Burton (antiquary, died 1645)|William Burton]] dedicated to him a translation of [[Achilles Tatius]]'s, ''[[Leucippe and Clitophon|Clitophon and Leucippe]]''.{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|p=54}}. On 4 October 1594 Southampton's friend, [[Henry Danvers, 1st Earl of Danby|Sir Henry Danvers]], shot Henry Long, brother of Sir Walter Long, in the course of a local feud between the Danvers and Long families. Sir Henry and his elder brother, [[Charles Danvers|Sir Charles Danvers]], fled to [[Titchfield]], where Southampton sheltered them. The brothers were outlawed, and eventually escaped to the continent where they took refuge at the court of [[Henri IV of France|King Henri IV]].{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=41–5}}. On 17 November 1595, Southampton [[jousting|jousted]] in Queen Elizabeth's [[Accession Day tilt|accession day tournament]], earning a mention in George Peele's ''Anglorum Feriae'' as "gentle and debonaire". However, according to Akrigg, "Gentle and debonair he may have been, but we never again hear of Southampton being high in the graces of Queen Elizabeth".{{harvnb|Akrigg|1968|p=48}}. On 13 April 1596 the Queen specifically instructed [[Robert Devereux, 2nd Earl of Essex]], not to take either Southampton or the [[William Stanley, 6th Earl of Derby|Earl of Derby]],According to Akrigg, Southampton and Derby were "rather close friends at this period"; {{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|p=56}}. with him on an expedition for the [[Siege of Calais (1596)|Relief of Calais]], and it also appears that Southampton did not accompany Essex on the [[Capture of Cádiz|Cadiz Expedition]] that summer.{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=56–9}}; Honan states that Southampton did go with Essex to Cadiz; {{Harvnb|Honan|2012}}. In February 1597 Southampton challenged the [[Henry Percy, 9th Earl of Northumberland|Earl of Northumberland]] to a duel with rapiers, requiring intervention by the Queen and Privy Council, and on 1 March stood godfather at the christening of [[Robert Sidney, 2nd Earl of Leicester|Sir Robert Sidney's]] daughter, Bridget. Later that year Southampton was with Essex on his "inglorious" [[Islands Voyage|Voyage to the Azores]], where according to Rowland Whyte, "My Lord of Southampton fought with one of the [[Philip II of Spain|Kings]] great Men of Warre, and suncke her". On his return he made his first appearance in the [[House of Lords]] on 5 November, and was put on several committees, but became a "chronic absentee". By this time he was in serious financial difficulties, and had turned over administration of his estates to two trustees, who by the end of the year had sold some of his lands.{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=58, 67}}. In 1598 Southampton was involved in a brawl at court with [[Ambrose Willoughby]],Ambrose Willoughby, second son of [[Charles Willoughby, 2nd Baron Willoughby of Parham]], is also mentioned in a letter of 17 June 1602 from [[John Chamberlain (letter writer)|John Chamberlain]] to [[Dudley Carleton, 1st Viscount Dorchester|Sir Dudley Carleton]]: "[[Grey Brydges, 5th Baron Chandos|Gray Bridges]] hath hurt Ambrose Willoughby in the heade and body, for abusing his father and himself at a conference of arbiterment twixt them and Mistris Bridges"; {{Harvnb|McClure|1939|p=150}}. one of the Queen's [[esquires of the body]], who had ordered him to leave the presence chamber where he was playing at [[primero]] after the Queen had retired for the evening. Southampton struck Willoughby, and "Willoughby puld of some of his locke", for which the Queen gave Willoughby thanks, saying "he had done better yf he had sent hym to the porters lodge, to see who durst have fetcht hym out".{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|p=68}}; {{Harvnb|Honan|2012}}. There is a suggestion that underlying the altercation was something Willoughby had said which caused trouble between Southampton and his mistress, [[Elizabeth Wriothesley, Countess of Southampton|Elizabeth Vernon]], one of the Queen's [[Maid of Honour|Maids of Honour]]. The Queen forbade Southampton to present himself at court, although he was soon allowed back. Nonetheless it was reported by Rowland Whyte at the beginning of February that "My Lord of Southampton is much troubled at her Majesties straungest Usage of hym". Faced with his financial difficulties and the Queen's disfavour, Southampton determined to live abroad for a time, and seized the opportunity of accompanying [[Robert Cecil, 1st Earl of Salisbury|Sir Robert Cecil]] on an embassy to [[Henri IV of France]]. On 6 February Southampton was granted licence to travel abroad for two years, and by March he and Cecil were in [[Angers]], where on 7 March Southampton was presented to the French King.{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=68–9}}. When Cecil returned to England from his failed mission in April, Southampton remained at the French court, planning to travel to Italy with [[Charles Danvers|Sir Charles Danvers]] and [[Henry Danvers, 1st Earl of Danby|Sir Henry Danvers]], whom he had helped to escape from England in 1594 after the murder of Henry Long. At that juncture the Queen decided to pardon the Danvers brothers, and they were back in England on 30 August 1598, at which time Southampton also returned in secret, and married his pregnant mistress, [[Elizabeth Wriothesley, Countess of Southampton|Elizabeth Vernon]]. He left for the continent almost immediately, but by 3 September the Queen had learned of the marriage and consigned Elizabeth Vernon, one of her chief ladies-in-waiting, to the [[Fleet Prison]] for marrying without royal permission. The Queen ordered Southampton to return to England forthwith, but he remained in Paris for two months, losing large sums in gambling. By the beginning of November he was back in England, also lodged in the Fleet, where he remained for a month, during which time Elizabeth Vernon gave birth to a daughter, Penelope. To add to his difficulties, Southampton was at this time involved in a dispute with his mother, the [[Mary Wriothesley, Countess of Southampton|Dowager Countess]], over her prospective marriage to [[William Hervey, 1st Baron Hervey|Sir William Hervey]]. [[Henry Howard, 1st Earl of Northampton|Lord Henry Howard]] was brought in to smooth matters between mother and son, and the Countess and Hervey were wed in early January 1599.{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=41–6, 69–74}}. In 1599, during the [[Nine Years War (Ireland)|Nine Years War]] (1595–1603), Southampton went to [[Essex in Ireland|Ireland with Essex]], who made him General of the Horse, but the Queen insisted that the appointment be cancelled. Southampton remained on in personal attendance upon the Earl, rather than as an officer. However, Southampton was active during the campaign and prevented a defeat at the hands of the Irish rebels when his cavalry drove off an attack at [[Arklow]] in [[County Wicklow]]. Shortly after the [[Essex's Rebellion]] in February 1601, William Reynolds, a soldier who had served with Essex in Ireland in 1599, mentioned Southampton in a letter to [[Robert Cecil, 1st Earl of Salisbury|Sir Robert Cecil]]. Speaking of certain men involved in the Essex rebellion who had not yet been arrested, Reynolds wrote:{{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|pp=181–2}}; {{Harvnb|Duncan-Jones|1993|pp=484–6}}; {{Harvnb|Honan|2012}}.
I do mervell also what becam of pearse edmones, the earle of Essex man, borne in strand neare me, and which has had many rewards & preferments by the earle essex, his villany I have often complained of, he dweles in London, he was corporall generall of the horse in Ierland under the earle of Sowthamton, he eate & drank at his table and lay in his tente, the earle of Sowthamton gave him a horse, which edmones refused a 100 markes for him, the earle Sowthamton would cole and huge him in his armes and play wantonly with him. This pearse began to fawne and flatter me in Ierland offering me great curtesie, telling me what pay grases & giftes they earles bestowed uppon him, therby seming to move and anymate me to desiar and looke for the like favour, But I coeld never love & afecte them to make them my frends, esspecially essex whoes mynd I ever mistrusted....
According to Duncan-Jones, Reynolds' letter hints that 'rewards could be obtained from either or both of the two Earls in return for sexual favours'. On the other hand, Duncan-Jones concludes that Reynolds may have been a paranoid schizophrenic, and that by his own statement he had written over 200 letters to the Queen, Privy Council, and members of the clergy wherein he had "complaynid of al the abewses and vilent oppresseones & sodometicall sines over flowing this land".{{Harvnb|Duncan-Jones|1993|pp=481, 482, 484}}. On his return from Ireland, Southampton attracted notice as a playgoer. "My Lord Southampton and Lord Rutland," wrote [[Rowland Whyte]] to [[Robert Sidney, 1st Earl of Leicester|Sir Robert Sydney]] in 1599, "come not to the court: the one doth but very seldom. They pass away the time in London merely in going to plays every day".{{Harvnb|Collier|1844|p=clxxiii}}; {{Harvnb|Akrigg|1968|p=96}}. Southampton was deeply involved in the [[Essex's Rebellion]] of 1601, and in February of that year he was sentenced to death. Cecil, who urged the Queen to show the greatest possible degree of clemency, obtained the [[Commutation of sentence|commutation]] of his penalty to [[life imprisonment]]. ==Life under King James== [[Image:HenryWriothesley 1594.jpg|thumb|200px|Southampton c.1600]] On the accession of [[James I of England|James I]] Southampton resumed his place at court and received numerous honours from the new king. On the eve of the abortive rebellion of Essex he had induced the players at the [[Globe Theatre]] to revive ''[[Richard II (play)|Richard II]]'', and on his release from prison in 1603 he resumed his connection with the stage. In January 1605 he entertained [[Anne of Denmark|Queen Anne]] with a performance of ''Love's Labour's Lost'' by [[Richard Burbage|Burbage]] and his company, to which Shakespeare belonged, at Southampton House.HMC: ''Manuscripts of the Marquis of Salisbury at Hatfield House'', vol.16, p.415, letter of Walter Cope to Robert Cecil about Burbage. He seems to have been a born fighter, and engaged in more than one serious quarrel at court, being imprisoned for a short time in 1603 following a heated argument with Lord Grey of Wilton in front of Queen Anne. Grey, an implacable opponent of the Essex faction, was later implicated in the [[Main Plot]] and [[Bye Plot]]. Southampton was in more serious disgrace in 1621 for his determined opposition to [[George Villiers, 1st Duke of Buckingham|Buckingham]]. He was a volunteer on the [[Protestant]] side in Germany in 1614, and in 1617 he proposed to fit out an expedition against the [[Barbary pirates]]. Southampton was a leader among the Jacobean aristocrats who turned to modern investment practices — "in industry, in modernizing their estates and in overseas trade and colonization."Margot Heinemann, "Rebel Lords, Popular Playwrights, and Political Culture: Notes on the Jacobean Patronage of the Earl of Southampton," in Brown; p. 139. He financed the first tinplate mill in the country, and founded an ironworks at [[Titchfield]]. He developed his properties in London, in [[Bloomsbury]] and [[Holborn]]; he revamped his country estates, participated in the efforts of the [[British East India Company|East India Company]] and the [[New England Company]], and backed [[Henry Hudson]]'s search for the [[Northwest Passage]]. A significant artistic patron in the Jacobean as well as the Elizabethan era, Southampton promoted the work of [[George Chapman]], [[Samuel Daniel]], [[Thomas Heywood]], and the composer [[Alfonso Ferrabosco the younger]]. Heywood's popular, expansionist dramas were compatible with Southampton's maritime and colonial interests.Consider Heywood's ''[[The Fair Maid of the West]]'', ''[[Fortune by Land and Sea]]'', and ''[[The Travels of the Three English Brothers]]''; Heinemann, pp. 142–7. ==Virginia Company== [[File:Henry Wriothesley 3rd Earl of Southampton after Daniel Mytens.jpg|left|thumb|The Earl of Southampton c.1618, after a portrait by [[Daniel Mytens]], [[National Portrait Gallery, London]].]] Henry Wriothesley, whose name is included in the 1605 panel of the [[New World Tapestry]], took a considerable share in promoting the colonial enterprises of the time, and was an active member of the [[Virginia Company of London|Virginia Company]]'s governing council. Although profits proved elusive, his other visions for the Colony based at [[Jamestown, Virginia|Jamestown]] were eventually accomplished. He was part of a faction within the company with Sir [[Edwin Sandys (died 1629)|Edwin Sandys]], who eventually became the Treasurer, and worked tirelessly to support the struggling venture. In addition to profits, Southampton's faction sought a permanent colony which would enlarge British territory, relieve the nation's overpopulation, and expand the market for English goods. Although profits largely eluded the Virginia Company, and it was dissolved in 1624, the other goals were accomplished. His name is thought by many to be the origin of the naming of the harbour of [[Hampton Roads]], and the [[Hampton River]]. Although named at later dates, similar attribution may involve the town (and later city) of [[Hampton, Virginia]], as well as [[Southampton County, Virginia]] and [[Northampton County, Virginia|Northampton County]]. However, the name [[Southampton]] was not uncommon in England, including an important port city and an entire region along the southern coast, which was originally part of [[Hampshire]]. There are also variations applied in other areas of the English colonies which were not part of the Virginia Company of London's efforts, making the origin of the word and derivations of it as applied in Virginia even more debatable. ==Later life and death== In 1624 Southampton was one of four Englishmen appointed to command troops fighting in the [[Low Countries]] against the [[Spain|Spanish]]. Shortly after their arrival the earl's eldest son, [[James Wriothesley, Lord Wriothesley|James Wriothesley]], succumbed to a fever at Rosendael. Five days later, on 10 November 1624, Southampton died of the same cause at [[Bergen-op-Zoom]], aged 51. Both were buried in the parish church of [[Titchfield]], [[Hampshire]]. ==Marriage and issue== [[Image:Elizabeth Vernon Countess of Southampton c 1618.jpg|right|thumb|200px|Elizabeth, Countess of Southampton c. 1618]] In August 1598 Southampton secretly married [[Elizabeth Wriothesley, Countess of Southampton|Elizabeth Vernon]], the daughter of John Vernon of [[Hodnet]], Shropshire, by his wife Elizabeth Devereux. Elizabeth Devereux's grandfathers were the Viscount Hereford and the Earl of Huntingdon; on her father John's side, Elizabeth's family were more obscure. They had several children, including: *Penelope Wriothesley, who married [[William Spencer, 2nd Baron Spencer of Wormleighton]]. *[[James Wriothesley, Lord Wriothesley]] (1 March 1605 – 5 November 1624), who died five days before his father, of the same illness. *[[Thomas Wriothesley, 4th Earl of Southampton]] (10 March 1607 – 16 May 1667). *Anne Wriothesley, who married [[Robert Wallop]] (20 July 1601 – 19 November 1667) of Farley Wallop. ==Portraits== There exist numerous portraits of Southampton, in which he is depicted with dark auburn hair and blue eyes, compatible with Shakespeare's description of "a man right fair." [[John Beaumont (poet)|Sir John Beaumont]] wrote a well-known elegy in his praise, and Gervase Markham wrote of him in a tract entitled ''Honor in his Perfection, or a Treatise in Commendation of ... Henry, Earl of Oxenford, Henry, Earle of Southampton, Robert, Earl of Essex'' (1624). In 2002 a portrait in the Cobbe collection was identified as a portrait of the youthful Earl. Showing him as an androgynous-looking young man, it is now known as the Cobbe [[Cobbe portrait#Cobbe portrait of Southampton|portrait of Southampton]].{{cite web| url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2002/apr/21/artsandhumanities.highereducation| author=Anthony Holden| title= That's no lady, that's...| publisher=[[The Observer]]| date=21 April 2002| accessdate=10 March 2009}} In April 2008, a further portrait believed to be of Southampton, hidden beneath a portrait of his wife Elizabeth Vernon, was discovered when the work was X-rayed in preparation for an exhibition.{{Cite book | title = X-rays uncover 'hidden portrait' | publisher = BBC News | date = 29 April 2008 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/7372629.stm}} ==In popular culture== The Earl has been played on screen by several different actors: *[[Peter Egan]] in the [[BBC]] mini-series ''[[Elizabeth R]]'', 1971. *[[Nicholas Clay]] in the TV series ''[[Will Shakespeare (TV series)|Life of Shakespeare]]'', 1978. *[[Eddie Redmayne]] in the [[Channel 4]] mini-series ''[[Elizabeth I (2005 miniseries)|Elizabeth I]]'', 2005. *[[Shaun Evans]] in the mini-series ''[[The Virgin Queen (TV serial)|The Virgin Queen]]'', 2006. *[[Xavier Samuel]] in the feature film ''[[Anonymous (film)|Anonymous]]'', 2011. *Adam Harley in the sitcom ''[[Upstart Crow]]'', 2016. ==Footnotes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== *{{Cite book |last=Akrigg |first=G.P.V. |year=1968 |title=Shakespeare and the Earl of Southampton |location=Cambridge, Massachusetts |publisher=Harvard University Press |ref=harv}} *{{Cite book |last=Rowse |first=A.L. |year=1965 |title=Shakespeare's Southampton: Patron of Virginia |location=London |publisher=Macmillan }} *{{Cite book |last=Cokayne |first=G.E. |year=1953 |title=The Complete Peerage edited by Geoffrey H. {{Lowercase title}} {{Infobox website |name = iAuthor Ltd. |company_type = Private |industry = [[Publishing]] |foundation = {{Start date|2012}} |launch_date = {{Start date|2013}} |founder = Adam Kolczynski |website_type = [[Recommender system|Content discovery]]
[[Social networking]]
[[eBooks]]
[[Advertising]] |location = [[London]], [[United Kingdom]] |advertising = [[Native advertising]] |language = [[English language|English]] |current status = Active |url = {{URL|https://www.iauthor.uk.com/|iAuthor.uk.com}} }} '''iAuthor''' is a [[London]]-based [[tech startup]] and online book community which launched in July 2013.{{Cite news |url=https://venturebeat.com/2013/07/26/iauthor-launches-out-of-beta-to-give-self-publishing-authors-a-louder-voice/|title=iAuthor launches out of beta to give self-publishing authors a louder voice, venturebeat.com |date= 26 July 2013| work=VentureBeat}} Described in [[The Bookseller]] as a "[[Pinterest]] for books",{{Cite news |url=http://www.thebookseller.com/futurebook/startup-week-iauthor-323850|title=Startup of the week: iAuthor, thebookseller.com |date= 7 March 2016| work=The Bookseller}} iAuthor connects authors and publishers to readers using [[crowdsourced]] themes and book samples.{{Cite news |url=http://www.adweek.com/galleycat/share-book-samples-online-with-iauthor/99830|title=Share Book Samples Online With iAuthor, adweek.com |date= 27 Feb 2015| work=GalleyCat}} ==History== iAuthor was founded by Adam Kolczynski on 18 January 2012.{{Cite news |url=http://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/07914235/filing-history|title=Companies House Filing History: iAuthor, companieshouse.gov.uk | work=Companies House}} Between December 2012 and July 2013, the platform operated in live [[betaware|beta]], capped at 250 users. iAuthor officially launched on July 26, 2013, opening the platform to all authors and publishers. As of March 2016, iAuthor attracts users from 144 countries. The ratio of traditionally published to self-published authors is 40:60, with books by authors from [[Pan Macmillan]], [[HarperCollins]], [[Harlequin Enterprises|Harlequin]], [[Walker Books]], Accent Press and [[Andersen Press]]. ==Features== *Seeded sorting of books by "Most Recommended" and "Most Followed"{{Cite news |url=http://www.crunchbase.com/organization/iauthor#/entity|title=CrunchBase: iAuthor, crunchbase.com | work=CrunchBase}} *[[Crowdsourced]] book themes with invite functionality{{Cite news |url=http://theliteraryplatform.com/magazine/2016/10/company-profile-iauthor//|title=Company Profile: iAuthor, theliteraryplatform.com | work=The Literary Platform}} *Proprietary book sampler ("LitSampler"){{Cite news |url=https://bookmachine.org/2016/09/13/iauthor-launches-book-sampling-tool/|title=iAuthor launches book sampling tool, bookmachine.org | work=BookMachine}} *Client-facing [[analytics]] dashboard measuring book performance *[[Native advertising]] across sponsored zones ("7dayAds") and genre-specific promotional packages ("iAuthor Impact"){{Cite news |url=http://iauthor.uk.com/advertise|title=Advertising on iAuthor, iauthor.uk.com | work=iAuthor}}{{Cite news |url=https://bookmachine.org/2016/03/19/startup-snapshot-iauthor/|title=iAuthor startup snapshot, bookmachine.org | work=BookMachine}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.selfpublishingformula.com/spf-038-iauthor/|title=Self Publishing Formula, www.selfpublishingformula.com | work=SPF Podcast}}{{Cite news |url=https://www.thebookseller.com/futurebook/drawing-subscribers-your-book-related-newsletter-7-insider-tips-776176|title=Drawing subscribers to your book-related newsletter, thebookseller.com |date= 27 April 2018| work=The Bookseller}} == Partnerships == iAuthor has a corporate partnership with [[Book Aid International]],{{Cite news|url=http://www.bookaid.org/support-us/trust-corporate-supporters/companies/|title=Supporters and corporate partners of Book Aid International, bookaid.org|work=Book Aid International}}{{Cite news |url=http://www.iauthor.uk.com/partnerships|title=iAuthor Partnerships, iauthor.uk.com | work=iAuthor}} donating to literacy-related causes organised by the charity. ==References== ==External links== *[https://www.iauthor.uk.com iAuthor official site] *[https://twitter.com/i_Author iAuthor on Twitter] *[https://www.facebook.com/pg/iauthor/about iAuthor on Facebook] [[Category:Book websites]] revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:La_Gloria_(Tiziano).jpg|thumb|290px|''La Gloria'']] '''''La Gloria''''' is a painting by [[Titian]], commissioned by [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles V]] in 1550 or 1551 and completed in 1554. It was first given this title by José Sigüenza in 1601 - it is also known as '''''The Trinity''''', '''''The Final Judgement''''' or '''''Paradise'''''.
It shows an image from [[Augustine of Hippo]]'s ''[[The City of God (book)|The City of God]]'' describing the glory gained by the blessed and on the right includes Charles himself, with his wife [[Isabella of Portugal]], his son [[Philip II of Spain]], his daughter [[Joanna of Austria, Princess of Portugal|Joanna of Austria]], [[Mary of Hungary (governor of the Netherlands)|Mary of Hungary]] and [[Eleanor of Austria]], all wearing their shrouds. Titian's signature is shown on a scroll held by [[John the Evangelist]]. At the top is an image of the [[Holy Trinity]] next to the Virgin Mary and [[Saint John the Baptist]]. The painting also features King David, Moses and Noah, along with a figure in green identified as [[Mary Magdalene]], the [[Erythraean Sibyl]], [[Book of Judith|Judith]], [[Rachel]] or the Catholic Church.
Charles took it to the [[Monastery of Yuste]] on his retirement there. It was then moved to the [[Escorial Monastery]] until 1837, when it was mentioned as among the works in the [[Prado Museum]].
==External links== *https://www.museodelprado.es/en/the-collection/art-work/the-glory/66149817-6f88-4e5f-a09a-81f63a84d145
{{Titian}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gloria, La}} [[category:Paintings by Titian]] [[category:1554 paintings]] [[Category:Collections of the Museo del Prado]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category:Birds in art]] [[Category:Books in art]] [[Category:Paintings of the Virgin Mary]]

This is a list of [[museum]]s with major [[art collection]]s from the [[Ancient Near East]].
* [[British Museum]], London, UK. 290,000 objects.<ref>[http://www.thebritishmuseum.ac.uk/ British Museum].</ref> * [[Pergamon Museum|Vorderasiatisches Museum]], Berlin, Germany. 250,000 objects.<ref>[http://www.smb.museum/en/museums-and-institutions/vorderasiatisches-museum/research.html Research] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714165916/http://www.smb.museum/en/museums-and-institutions/vorderasiatisches-museum/research.html |date=2014-07-14 }}, SMB.museum.</ref> * [[National Museum of Iraq]], Baghdad, Iraq.170,000 objects.<ref>[http://arts.guardian.co.uk/news/story/0,,946258,00.html Article], ''[[The Guardian]]''.</ref> * [[Musée du Louvre]], Paris, France. 100,000 objects.<ref>2005 Annual Report – Tableau récapitulatif de l’état d'avancement de l'informatisation des collections fin 2005, page 185.</ref> * [[Oriental Institute, Chicago|Oriental Institute]], Chicago. 20,000 objects<ref>[http://maroon.uchicago.edu/news/articles/2003/10/09/new_exhibit_will_fea.php New exhibit] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20040217085024/http://maroon.uchicago.edu/news/articles/2003/10/09/new_exhibit_will_fea.php |date=2004-02-17 }}, [[University of Chicago]], 2003.</ref> * [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York. 7,000 objects<ref>[http://www.metmuseum.org/Works_of_Art/introduction.asp?dep=3 Works of Art], [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], USA.</ref> * [[Istanbul Archaeology Museums|Istanbul Archaeology Museum]], Istanbul, Turkey. * [[University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology]], Pennsylvania.<ref>[http://www.museum.upenn.edu/new/exhibits/galleries/neareast.shtml Near East], [[University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology]].</ref> * [[Rijksmuseum van Oudheden]], Leiden, The Netherlands. * [[Israel Museum]],Jerusalem, Israel. * [[Eretz Israel Museum]], Tel Aviv, Israel. * [[Hecht Museum]], Haifa, Israel. * [[Bible Lands Museum]], Jerusalem, Israel. * [[Semitic Museum]], Cambridge, Massachusetts.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Museums of Ancient Middle East}} [[Category:Lists of art museums|Ancient Near East Art]] [[Category:Museums of Ancient Near East|*]] [[Category:Ancient Near East art and architecture]]

revision.text:
The '''Marín Dolls Museum-Factory''' ('''Fábrica-Museo Muñecas Marín''') is located in [[Chiclana de la Frontera]], in the [[province of Cádiz]], [[Andalusia]], southwestern [[Spain]]. The doll museum is located next to the doll factory. The factory was established in 1928,<ref name="YuberoConde2001">{{cite book|last1=Yubero|first1=Consuelo|last2=Conde|first2=Javier|title=Jugamos a las muñecas?: las muñecas de nuestras madres|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YecmAQAAIAAJ|accessdate=14 January 2012|date=1 November 2001|publisher=Espasa|language=Spanish|isbn=978-84-239-5696-8|page=22}}</ref> by the artist José Marín Verdugo (1903-1984). By the mid 20th century, the dolls were sold not only in Spain, but also in other European countries. In 1976, the Spanish government granted the Medal of Merit of Labor to the Chiclana José Marín Verdugo factory. [[Krakow, Poland]] honored it with the First World Doll Award. It is currently run by Ana Marín, daughter of the founder.<ref name="conmishijos.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.conmishijos.com/ocio-fuera-de-casa/ocio-list/museo-de-munecas-marin-chiclana-cadiz.html|title=MUSEO DE MUÑECAS MARÍN, CHICLANA (CÁDIZ)|work=conmishijos.com|language=Spanish|accessdate=14 January 2012}}</ref> The Government of Spain granted to José Marín Verdugo 's Medal of Merit Labor in 1976.
==Museum== The museum provides information on the factory building and its traditional Marín dolls, which they won the First Prize Muñequería World. Opened in 1997, the museum's goal is to showcase the various doll types created by the craft factory. It has a large collection of handmade dolls and molds, antique designs and original sculptures. The museum is open weekdays.
==Factory== Doll making at the Chiclana factory became a feminized job,<ref name="Mujer2001">{{cite book|author=Cádiz (Spain). Fundación de la Mujer|title=Mujeres emprendedoras gaditanas de un siglo, 1900-2000|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NRK3AAAAIAAJ|accessdate=14 January 2012|year=2001|publisher=Universidad de Cádiz, Servicio de Publicaciones|language=Spanish}}</ref> using artisan production methods to create the hand made dolls. The original dolls were dressed in typical Andalusian [[flamenco]] attire. Others were produced later to depict costumes from other regions, such as the ''chulapa'' of [[Madrid]] and the [[Valencian people|Valencian]] ''fallas''. Since its inception, it has demonstrated traditional doll making techniques,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spain.info/en/conoce/museo/cadiz/fabrica-museo_de_munecos_marin.html |title=Fábrica-Museo de Muñecos Marín - Marín Dolls Museum-Factory |publisher=Spain.info.en |accessdate=12 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120054633/http://www.spain.info/en/conoce/museo/cadiz/fabrica-museo_de_munecos_marin.html |archivedate=20 January 2012 |df= }}</ref> in hair, makeup, and facial expressions. The dolls are easily recognized by their dainty features and smiling faces. The factory has been a reference point for Andalusian economic activity.<ref name="chiclana.costasur.com">{{cite web|url=http://chiclana.costasur.com/en/museo-marin.html|title=Factory Museum of Muñecas Marín in Chiclana de la Frontera, Costa de la Luz, Cádiz |work=chiclana.costasur.com|accessdate=14 January 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120121085842/http://www.marindolls.com/ Official website]
{{coord|36.4433|-6.1372|type:landmark_region:ES|display=title}}

{{About|the [[Christian artists|Christian artist]] specializing in [[Batik]]|the present [[Diocese of Medak|Bishop - in - Medak]]|A. C. Solomon Raj}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox clergy | child = | honorific_prefix = [[The Reverend]] | name = P. Solomon Raj | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | pronunciation = | birth_name = Puldindi Solomon Raj | birth_date = 1921P. Solomon Raj, ''Fiery Wheels: Art Works and Meditations'', Lalit Kala Ashram, Vijayawada, 2003, inside back cover. | birth_place = [[Andhra Pradesh]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = [[Vijayawada]], [[Krishna District]], [[Andhra Pradesh]] | nationality = [[Indian people|Indian]] | other_names = | citizenship = [[India]] | education = [[Bachelor of Divinity|B. D.]] ([[Senate of Serampore College (University)|Serampore]]),
[[Master of Arts|M. A.]] ([[Indiana University|Indiana]]),
[[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] ([[University of Birmingham|Birmingham]]) | alma_mater =[[Andhra Christian College]], [[Guntur]] ([[Andhra Pradesh]]),
[[Gurukul Lutheran Theological College]], [[Chennai]] ([[Tamil Nadu]]),
[[Indiana University Bloomington]] ([[United States]]),
[[Selly Oak Colleges]], [[Birmingham]] ([[England]]) | occupation = [[Pastor]] and [[Christian art]]ist | years_active = | home_town = | parents = | website = | religion = [[Christianity]] | church = [[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church]] | ordained =1956 | writings = | congregations =[[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church]] Society | offices_held =Director, ''Suvartha Vani'', [[Vijayawada]] | title = The Reverend Doctor | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} {{Portal|Lutheranism}} '''P. Solomon Raj''' ''(born 1921)'' is a pastor of the [[Protestant]] [[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church]] Society headquartered in [[Guntur]] with major contribution to theological research and arts.Volker Kuester, ''Renunciation of Inculturation as an Aesthetic Resistance: The Indian artist Solomon Raj seen in a new light'' in ''Fiery Wheels: Art Works and Meditations'', Lalit Kala Ashram, Vijayawada, 2003, pp.100–111 The [[Old Testament]] scholar [[Victor Premasagar]] wrote about Raj as a pastor, professor of communications, creative artist, sculptor, poet and a theological writer. The church historian, K. L. Richardson of the [[Andhra Christian Theological College]], [[Hyderabad]], [[India]], in ''Towards Self-Reliance: A historical survey of the programmes and efforts of Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church from 1927–1969, Published by D. Christopher and T. Kanakaiah, Vijayawada, 2003K. L. Richardson, ''Towards Self-Reliance: A historical survey of the programmes and efforts of Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church from 1927–1969, Published by D. Christopher and T. Kanakaiah, Vijayawada, 2003, pp.120, 133, 134''. has highlighted the contribution of Raj with special reference to Indian liturgy and music. Richardson writes, {{quote|''(Adapted)'' During 1960s, Rev. P. Solomon Raju contributed very much to the AELC on indigenous methods through his writings, seminars and other special efforts. Many Christian plays, [[Burra katha]]s and [[Hari Katha]]s were written in Telugu by the distinguished writers and musicians including Solomon Raj.}} Much like theologians of India believing in the Indian ethos akin to [[A. B. Masilamani]], [[D. S. Amalorpavadass]], [[Victor Premasagar]], [[M. Victor Paul]] and others, Raj believes that it is only that form of Christianity, deeply etched in the diverse cultures of India, that can affect Christianity in India. While [[A. B. Masilamani]] promoted Indian liturgy in the Christian Hymnal in Telugu, [[D. S. Amalorpavadass]] advocated for vernacular liturgy. Similarly, Victor Premasagar had recognised the contribution of indigenous movements. [[M. Victor Paul]] rooted for indigenous churches in place of institutionalized ones. It is in such a setting that Raj's contribution gains credence in the light of his doctoral dissertation on the Bible Mission Movement by Father Devadas which [[Roger E. Hedlund]] writes as, {{quote|Solomon Raj shows that the traditional mission-founded Churches are really ''Western'' appendages. This is true of the Lutherans and other traditional denominations including the Church of South India and the Church of North India. Solomon Raj predicts that movements such as this one (Bible Mission of Fr. Devadas) will have an ever increasing influence upon Christianity in India.Roger E. Hedlund, ''Quest for Identity: India's Churches of Indigenous Origin: the "Little Tradition" in Indian Christianity'', published by the ISPCK for Mylapore Institute for Indigenous Studies, Madras, 2006, p.75.}} As an artist, Raj received global acclaim. Gudrun Löwner of the [[United Theological College, Bangalore]] has devoted a section in ''The Oxford Handbook of Christianity in AsiaGudrun Löwner, ''Christian Art and Architecture in Asia'' in Felix Wilfred (Edited), The Oxford Handbook of Christianity in Asia, Oxford University Press, 2014, pp.458–476. [https://books.google.com/books?id=CtNjAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA468&dq=lutheran+solomon+raj&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CC8Q6AEwBGoVChMIwLbkhPCIxwIV1gqOCh1G4A1R#v=onepage&q=lutheran%20solomon%20raj&f=false]'', {{quote|Still alive and creative is the Lutheran theologian and artist, Solomon Raj who uses batik and woodcuts, which use cheap materials that are readily available. He depicts Jesus amidst the refugees and suffering people. The artist's favourite story is John 4, where he shows the liberative message of Jesus taking water from an untouchable woman, something which is still distant reality in South Indian villages, where the Dalits are not allowed to take water from the wells of others since they are considered 'polluting'.}} ==Early education and studies== ===Graduate studies=== Raj underwent initial studies between 1940–1945 at the AELC-[[Andhra Christian College]], [[Guntur]] and became a teacher. During the tenure of [[A. N. Gopal]] as president of the [[Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church]] Society, Raj was sent for theological studies to the [[Gurukul Lutheran Theological College]], [[Madras]], where he studied from 1953–1956, studying under thoroughbred faculty, including Professor Hans-Werner Gensichen. ===Post-graduate studies=== In 1964 during the tenure of [[G. Devasahayam]] at the AELC Church Society, Raj was sent for post-graduate studies to the [[Indiana University]], [[Indiana]], where he completed a master's degree in education. ===Doctoral studies=== When the [[Selly Oak Colleges]], Birmingham invited Raj to lecture in communication for term between 1978–1983, Raj not only taught at the college but also enrolled as a doctoral candidate and pursued research studies under the guidance of Walter Hollenweger. Raj also spent time at the [[Lutheran School of Theology at Chicago]]. ===Art student=== As an artist, Raj first learnt the nuances of art through the [[Sunday School]] and later became a student of the notable artist, [[Damerla Rama Rao]] and cleared a state examination in drawing and painting. While at the [[Indiana University]], he learnt woodblock printing and etching. As for batik, he learnt it from his friends in [[Hyderabad]]. ==Career== The career graph of Raj shows him as a teacher, pastor, administrator, professor and as an artist. ===Pastor=== Although Raj began his career as a teacher, he soon became a pastor of the Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church Society serving as a chaplain of the AELC-[[Andhra Christian College]], Guntur serving during 1956–1959. He then served at the Lutheran Theological College, [[Rajahmundry]] for a year, 1959–1960. ===Administrator=== In 1960, on the invitation of the [[National Council of Churches in India]] (NCCI), he took up the directorship of the Department for Audio-Visual education and served in [[Nagpur]], the headquarters of the NCCI from 1960–1968. In 1968, he moved to [[Vijayawada]] to take up a role as director of the radio station, ''Suvartha VaniFrancis Peter Barboza, ''Christianity in Indian Dance Forms'', Sri Satguru Publications, 1990, p. 193. [https://books.google.com/books?id=0DfkAAAAMAAJ&q=suvartha+vani+p.+solomon+raj&dq=suvartha+vani+p.+solomon+raj&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDQQ6AEwBmoVChMIh8f9-p6IxwIVTG2OCh1aIgNH]'', a multimedia project of the Andhra Pradesh Council of Churches, serving during the period 1968–1978. K. L. Richardson writes that ''Rev. P. Solomon Raj of the AELC who had rich experience in radio evangelism also served in the programme of Suvartha Vani''. ===Professor=== Raj took up professorship and lectured at the Selly Oak Colleges, Birmingham, from 1978–1983, where he taught communication. Raj was visiting lecturer in the United States of America during 1984–1985. ==Contribution== Scholars down the line have acknowledged the contribution of Raj to theology and art. ===Writings=== [[Ravela Joseph]] and [[B. Suneel Bhanu]], who had undertaken a compilation in 1993 entitled ''Bibliography of original Christian writings in India in Telugu'' on behalf of the [[Board of Theological Education of the Senate of Serampore College]], acknowledged Raj to be one of the original Christian writers[[Ravela Joseph]] and [[B. Suneel Bhanu]] (Compiled), ''Bibliography of original Christian writings in India in Telugu'', [[Board of Theological Education of the Senate of Serampore College]], Bangalore, 1993, pp.3, 20, 29, 36, 40 and 67. in Telugu. They have listed out the following works by Raj, *in 1957, How to Study the Bible,P. Solomon Raj, ''How to Study the Bible'', Christian Publishing House, Rajahmundry, 1957. Cited by Ravela Joseph and Suneel Bhanu in ''Bibliography of original Christian writings in India in Telugu, BTESSC, Bangalore, 1993. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3YPgAAAAMAAJ&dq=bibliography+of+original+christian+writings+in+telugu&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAWoVChMImNaxrsmIxwIVyo-OCh1TAwC6] *in 1957, Story TellingP. Solomon Raj, ''Story Telling'', Christian Publishing House, Rajahmundry, 1959. Cited by Ravela Joseph and Suneel Bhanu in ''Bibliography of original Christian writings in India in Telugu, BTESSC, Bangalore, 1993. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3YPgAAAAMAAJ&dq=bibliography+of+original+christian+writings+in+telugu&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAWoVChMImNaxrsmIxwIVyo-OCh1TAwC6] *in 1973, Wild FlowersP. Solomon Raj, ''Wild Flowers'', Christian Literature Society, Hyderabad, 1973. Cited by Ravela Joseph and Suneel Bhanu in ''Bibliography of original Christian writings in India in Telugu, BTESSC, Bangalore, 1993. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3YPgAAAAMAAJ&dq=bibliography+of+original+christian+writings+in+telugu&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAWoVChMImNaxrsmIxwIVyo-OCh1TAwC6] *in 1977, A Theological DictionaryP. Solomon Raj, ''A Theological Dictionary'', St. John's Publications, Hyderabad, 1977. Cited by Ravela Joseph and Suneel Bhanu in ''Bibliography of original Christian writings in India in Telugu, BTESSC, Bangalore, 1993. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3YPgAAAAMAAJ&dq=bibliography+of+original+christian+writings+in+telugu&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAWoVChMImNaxrsmIxwIVyo-OCh1TAwC6] *in 1978, Christ, the King of KingsP. Solomon Raj, ''Christ, the King of Kings'', Christian Literature Society, Hyderabad, 1978. Cited by Ravela Joseph and Suneel Bhanu in ''Bibliography of original Christian writings in India in Telugu, BTESSC, Bangalore, 1993. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3YPgAAAAMAAJ&dq=bibliography+of+original+christian+writings+in+telugu&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAWoVChMImNaxrsmIxwIVyo-OCh1TAwC6] *in 1978, The House of WorshipP. Solomon Raj, ''The House of Worship'', Christian Literature Society, Hyderabad, 1978. Cited by Ravela Joseph and Suneel Bhanu in ''Bibliography of original Christian writings in India in Telugu, BTESSC, Bangalore, 1993. [https://books.google.com/books?id=3YPgAAAAMAAJ&dq=bibliography+of+original+christian+writings+in+telugu&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAWoVChMImNaxrsmIxwIVyo-OCh1TAwC6] In addition to the books listed out, Raj has also authored, * in 1986, A Christian Folk Religion in India: A study of the small Church movement in Andhra Pradesh with special reference to the Bible Mission of Devadas.P. Solomon Raj, ''A Christian Folk Religion in India: A study of the small Church movement in Andhra Pradesh with special reference to the Bible Mission of Devadas'', Peter Lang, Frankfurt, 1986. Second edition in 2004 published by the Centre for Contemporary Christianity, Bangalore,[http://cfccbangalore.com/Publications_Default.aspx?001~~~4~~~4 Centre for Contemporary Christianity, Bangalore] * in 1993, Living flame and Springing Fountain: Batiks and Meditations,P. Solomon Raj, ''Living flame and Springing Fountain: Batiks and Meditations'', ISPCK, New Delhi, 1993. * in 2003, Fiery Wheels: Art works and meditations, * in 2003, New Wine Skins: The Story of the Indigenous Missions in coastal Andhra Pradesh.P. Solomon Raj, ''New Wine Skins: The Story of the Indigenous Missions in coastal Andhra Pradesh'', published by the ISPCK, New Delhi for the Mylapore Institute for Indigenous Studies, Madras, 2003 ===Arts=== Art forms interested Raj since his [[Sunday School]] days, and he soon got to show his arts from the later half of the 1960s. He was Artist-in-Residence in United States of America, Great Britain, Canada, Japan and [[Philippines]] ''(Asian Institute for Liturgy and Music, Manila)''. He held art shows and gave lectures in United Kingdom, United States of America, Japan, [[Sweden]], [[Finland]], Germany, [[Netherlands]] and the [[Philippines]]. ==Scholarly appraisal== * H. L. Richard,[http://cms.fuller.edu/EIFD/Authors/Richard,_H_L.aspx Fuller Theological Seminary] Research Scholar, [[Fuller Theological Seminary]], Fuller, {{quote|Solomon RajH. L. Richard in ''New Wine Skins: The Story of the Indigenous Missions in coastal Andhra Pradesh'', published by the ISPCK, New Delhi for the Mylapore Institute for Indigenous Studies, Madras, 2003 is a gifted artist particularly in [[Batik]]s where he specialised in Biblical themes while drawing on Indian cultural symbols. This makes him a rare bird among Indian Christians, but the combination of artist and missiologist is still more rare.}} * Volker Küster,[http://www.ev.theologie.uni-mainz.de/eng/3335.php Johannes Gutenberg Universität, Mainz] Professor of Comparative Religion and Missiology, [[Johannes Gutenberg Universität, Mainz]], {{quote|By critical spirits among the visitors of his exhibitions, the batiks of Solomon Raj are often regarded as nice and harmless.}} * Karel Steenbrink,[http://www.uu.nl/hum/staff/KASteenbrink1/0 Utrecht University] Emeritus Professor, Department of Philosophy and Religious Studies, [[Utrecht University]], {{quote|Solomon Raj is a true universal Christian artist blending a Christian vision with the language of International Art using for example, Indian symbols, Indonesian Batik technique, Japanese woodcut and some stereotypes of orthodox icons – all this with a powerful and very personal new style. His art works are loved and admired by many people all over the world.}} * Fr. Peter Balleis, SJ, Mission Procurator, [[Nurnberg]], {{quote|...one could hardly overlook his (Solomon Raj's) presence, which was visible in the form of a good number of his artistic works in some of our offices and corridors.}} ==Recognition and honours== In 1986, Raj was elected as the president of the Indian Christian Art Association. In 1987–88, Raj was William Paton Fellow at the Selly Oak Colleges, Birmingham. In 2006, a postgraduate candidate at the [[Utrecht University]], Jojanneke Dekker undertook a research on the works of Raj entitled ''Solomon Raj, Prophetic Artist in India: A Research on Dr. P. Solomon Raj's Art as a Medium of Inculturation of the Gospel in India''.Jojanneke Dekker, ''Solomon Raj, Prophetic Artist in India: A Research on Dr. P. Solomon Raj's Art as a Medium of Inculturation of the Gospel in India'', Utrecht University, Utrecht, 2006. Cited by Jan Peter Schouten in ''Jesus as Guru: The Image of Christ among Hindus and Christians in India'', Rodopi, p.266. [https://books.google.com/books?id=pIoKdTH7KPsC&pg=PA266&dq=p.+solomon+raj&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCsQ6AEwA2oVChMIhbaXn76IxwIVkQmOCh3i2Qhd#v=onepage&q=p.%20solomon%20raj&f=false] {{S-start}} {{s-aca}} {{Succession box| before=-| title=Honorary Fellow,
[[Selly Oak Colleges]], Birmingham | after=-| years=1991}} {{S-end}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal | author=Felix Wilfred (Edited) | title=''The Oxford Handbook of Christianity in Asia'' | year=2014 | volume= | issue= | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=CtNjAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA468&dq=lutheran+solomon+raj&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CC8Q6AEwBGoVChMIwLbkhPCIxwIV1gqOCh1G4A1R#v=onepage&q=lutheran%20solomon%20raj&f=false }} * {{cite journal | author=Anand Amaladass, Gudrun Löwner | title=''Christian Themes in Indian Art: From the Mogul Times Till Today'' | year=2012 | volume= | issue= | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=RI_HtwAACAAJ&dq=Christian+Themes+in+Indian+Art&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiPqqnJppTPAhUMwWMKHWPUAyQQ6AEIGzAA }} * {{cite journal | author=Jojanneke Dekker | title=''Solomon Raj, Prophetic Artist in India: A Research on Dr. P. Solomon Raj's Art as a Medium of Inculturation of the Gospel in India'' | year=2006 | volume= | issue= | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=pIoKdTH7KPsC&pg=PA266&dq=p.+solomon+raj&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCsQ6AEwA2oVChMIhbaXn76IxwIVkQmOCh3i2Qhd#v=onepage&q=p.%20solomon%20raj&f=false }} * {{cite journal | author=Kolluri Luther Richardson | title=''Towards Self-Reliance : A historical survey of the programmes and efforts of Andhra Evangelical Lutheran Church from 1927–1969'', Published by Christopher and Kanakaiah, Vijayawada | year=2003 | volume= | issue= | url = }} * {{cite journal | author=[[R. Joseph]] and [[B. Suneel Bhanu]] | title=''Bibliography of Original Christian Writings in India in Telugu'' | year=1993 | volume= | issue= | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=3YPgAAAAMAAJ&dq=Bibliography+of+Original+Christian+Writings+in+India+in+Telugu }} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Raj, Solomon P.}} [[Category:Indian Lutherans]] [[Category:Indian Christian theologians]] [[Category:Telugu people]] [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:Christian artists]] [[Category:Christian clergy from Andhra Pradesh]] [[Category:Senate of Serampore College (University) alumni]] [[Category:Indiana University alumni]] [[Category:20th-century Indian translators]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Painters from Andhra Pradesh]]
